title-group.article-title: Financial Goals and Debt Ratio Determinants: A Survey of Practice in Five Countries

permissions.copyright-statement: Copyright 1975 Board of Regents of the University of Wisconsin System

abstract.p: The authors compare the ranking of corporate financial goals and debt ratio determinants by financial executives of manufacturing corporations in France, Japan, The Netherlands, Norway, and the United States. The comparison is based on a survey in 1972-73 of financial executives in 87 firms conducted by an international consortium of finance professors and practitioners. Whereas theorists prescribe a financial goal of maximizing stockholder wealth, the financial executives surveyed prefer a financial goal of maximizing growth in corporate earnings, either in total (France, Japan, and The Netherlands), EBIT (Norway), or per share (the United States). The "traditional school" prescribes that a firm should choose its debt ratio to minimize cost of capital, but the financial executives surveyed concern themselves more about financial risk and the availability of capital than its cost.
